values: But I'm deleting this journal.  Before you all start yelling at me, I'm starting a new one.  This journal belongs to some crazy woman who lived in Anderson and then moved in with her parents for nearly two years.  And let's face it, people, she was a whiney twit.  For all of you who put up with me through all that shit, thanks.  You rock.  :)  For those of you who somehow missed it . . . what are you doing reading my journal, exactly?  Anyway, I determined that a lot of why I hadn't been posting had to do with the associations I have with this journal.   So, I'm going.  All the cool kids will be added to my new friends list post-haste.  If for some reason I don't add you, go away; you're too ugly to be loved.  Oh, no, wait, I mean that's because I'm stupid, so drop me a line so's I can add you.  So ends this chapter in the life of Becky.

Your soul is bound to the Black Rose: The
Wicked. "I am the wicked specemin of sin with no
profound logic to believe in. Hold me tight,
but don't hold me close, I go where I
desire." The Black Rose is associated with manipulation,
control, and virtuosity. It is governed by the
goddess Psyche and its sign is The Tapestry, or
Crafted Love. As a Black Rose, you may have a slight wicked
streak running through you. But whether you
are naughty or nice is up for debate. You know
how to get what you want and can work people
for what they're worth. You have great people
skills, but can sometimes be a bit of a control
freak.

What Rose Is Your Soul Bound To?
brought to you by Quizilla

To All True Americans:  Be on the Alert

At New York's Kennedy airport today, an individual later discovered to be a
public school teacher was arrested trying to board a flight while in
possession of a ruler, a protractor, a setsquare, a slide rule, and a
calculator.

At a morning press conference, Attorney general John Ashcroft said he
believes the man is a member of the notorious al-gebra movement. He is being
charged by the FBI with carrying weapons of math instruction.

"Al-gebra is a fearsome cult," Ashcroft said. "They desire average solutions
by means and extremes, and sometimes go off on tangents in a search of
absolute value. They use secret code names like "x" and "y" and refer to
themselves as "unknowns", but we have determined they belong to a common
denominator of the axis of medieval with coordinates in every country.

"As the Greek philanderer Isosceles used to say, there are 3 sides to every
triangle," Ashcroft declared.

When asked to comment on the arrest, President Bush said, "If God had wanted
us to have better weapons of math instruction, He would have given us more
fingers and toes.

"I am gratified that our government has given us a sine that it is intent on
protracting us from these math-dogs who are willing to disintegrate us with
calculus disregard. Murky statisticians love to inflict plane on every
sphere of influence," the President said, adding: "Under the circumferences,
we must differentiate their root, make our point, and  draw the line."

President Bush warned, "These weapons of math instruction have the potential
to decimal everything in their math on a scalene never before seen unless we
become exponents of a Higher Power and begin to factor-in random facts of
vertex."

Attorney General Ashcroft said, "As our Great Leader would say, read my
ellipse. Here is one principle he is uncertainty of: though they continue to
multiply, their days are numbered as the hypotenuse tightens around their
necks."

MR SAM ARONU
AUDITING AND ACCOUNTING UNIT.
FOREIGN REMITTANCE DEPT.
ECO BANK,COTONOU, 
REPUBLIC OF BENIN
DIRECT TEL 00-229-483-784.

Dear good friend,

I am MR.Sam Aronu,the director in charge of auditing and accounting section of ECO BANK OF COTONOU REPUBLIC OF

During our investigation and auditing in this bank, my department came across a very huge sum of money belonging to a

account with this Bank without any  claim of the fund in our custody either from his family or relation before our discovery to this 
development.

Although personally,I keep this information secret within myself and partners to enable the whole plans and idea be profitable 
and successful. During the time of execution. The said amount was us$21.5M(TWENTY ONE MILLION FIVE HUNDRED 
THOUSAND UNITED SATES DOLLARS).

Meanwhile all the whole arrangement to put claim over this fund  with you as the bonafide next of kin to the deceased, and  
transfer this money to a foreign account  has been put in place and directives and needed information will be relayed to you as 
soon as you indicate your interest and willingness to assist us and also benefit your self in this great business opportunity.In 
fact I could have done this deal alone but because of my position in this country as a civil servant,we are not allowed to operate 
a foreign account and would eventually raise an eye brow on my side during the time of transfer because I work in this  bank. 
This is the actual reason why it will require a second party or fellow who will forward claims as The next of kin will present to the

transferred into on his request as it may be after due verification and clarification by the correspondent branch of the

I will not fail to inform you that this transactionis 100% risk free.On smooth conclusion of this transaction, you will be entitled to

Please,you have been adviced to keep top secret as we are still in service and intend to retire from service after we conclude

All other necessary information will be sent to you when I hear from you.I suggest you get back to me as soon as possible

CALL ME UP RECEIPT OF THIS MESSAGES FOR MORE DETAILS
ON MY TELEPHONE NUMBER 00-229-483-784.FOR MORE DETAILS

Best Regard,
MR.Sam Aronu

Faites un voeu et puis Voila ! www.voila.fr
I am very fond of music.  I am also fond of typing.  And rum.  And pirates.  I am fond of a lot of things, which makes me awfully lucky, I think.
I updated to the new version of AOL last night.  My computer no longer recognizes my mouse.  Peachy.

I was on the playa, only I wasn't really.  I was in my apartment, but the back door of my apartment led out to the playa.  The surreality of this was really brought home by the fact that I knew, even in my dream, that we live in a third floor apartment.  I could walk out my front door and I would be in Concord, but if I walked out my back door, I would be in Black Rock City.  My back door was always open, and sometimes I'd wake up to find dusty, costumed strangers on my couches (I had neon inflatable couches, and one loveseat covered in soft white material, with a red throw over the back).  It was like living halfway between a dream and reality, only it was impossible to tell which was which.
I have decided to quit my job and become a mercenary ninja in Sri Lanka.
I just received an email that informed me that the position I was supposed to interview for on Wednesday has already been filled, so don't bother to show up.  Um, ew.  Rude.

Um, hi, all.  So, I love you guys dearly, and I really, really do like seeing everyone's photos, but my friends screen is more than twice as wide as my moniter, and I can't read anything, so could people start posting their pictures behind links, pretty please with a cherry on top?  Thanks.  :)

This afternoon, I applied for a nifty-cool copy editing job in Oakland, that happens to be conveniently located two blocks from MacArthur BART (and, therefore, three blocks from <lj user="abazureonna"> and <lj user="sea_and_sky">'s place, which is a nice perk), and they wrote back to me in less than two hours.  I'm supposed to go in for editing tests on either the 20th or the 21st, which is kind of exciting since that's around when my current work schedule may be changing, and I don't know when to make my appointment for, or what to say to my current employer that won't tip them off to the fact that I'm interviewing for another job.  But, yay!  Happy!

And Burning Man in 2 1/2 weeks!  Eep!  Yay!

The word "manga" is now a registered trademark.

Me First and the Gimmie Gimmies have a new album.

I'm going to Burning Man in twenty-one days.

My bathroom is now fully equipped with Hello Kitty merchandize, courtesy of my mother.  This includes the ever-popular Hello Kitty toilet brush.  No vibrator, though.

How compatible with me are YOU?

Instruments are very addictive.  My hands hurt, my arms ache, and my choulders feel like someone is stabbing knives into them.  The only thing keeping me from playing is that it's 2:00 a.m. and I don't want to wake my neighbors.  In my next life, I'm going to play something that can be played quietly.

"The thing about living forever is that you never know when you're done."
-
 There are some things that no one can take from me: my friends, my family, my music, my writing, my gods. I can let them go, and maybe I have too much lately, but no one can take them, and since I can't really think of anything more important, I guess that makes me pretty damn lucky.

"Decide what is sacred to you, and put your best life energies at its service. Make that the focus of your studies, your work, the test for your pleasures and your relationships. Don't ever let fear or craving for security turn you aside. When you serve your passion, when you are willing to risk yourself for something, your greatest creative energies are released. Hard work is required, but nothing is more joyful than work infused by love."
-Starhawk

So, the cooling fan isn't working.  My father is going to stop by probably on Tuesday with gadgets for figuring out how to fix it.  The good news is that the car is drivable; it just can't sit still with the engine running.  So, if I get stuck in traffic, I have to pull over, stop the engine, and wait until the traffic goes away, and I have to run the heater if I get stuck at a long red light, but I am not, in any way, stuck at home, which is good.
I really should stop holding out for a basic sense of justice in humanity

So, even though I was supposed to start training for my new position today (okay, I got to train for 20 minutes), the project that I was assigned before I got promoted is apparently far more important than having a full supervisory staff and no one else is available to do it. So, not only did I spend seven hours doing mindless, exhausting, frustrating work that, by all rights, should have already been done by someone else (oh, yeah, did I mention this project involves cleaning up someone else's colossal mess?), but I have to spend the rest of the week doing it AND I have to get up at FIVE O'CLOCK IN THE FUCKING MORNING for the remainder of the week. Grar.

So, out of thin air, I did get promoted, but not to the position I applied for. This is actually quite okay by me, since I'd much rather have the position that I'm going to have than the one I applied for and I could still take all of my academic classes (none of the music, though, since they're all midday three days a week and I need to work 5 days) and maybe a dance class, too. So the question is: jazz or modern? "People don't usually say hello with their tongues. Well, okay; I guess they do." -Spike

Walking in Oakland is a very unique experience.  Despite the complete urbanity, there's something very earthy and primal about the city, as though humanity's marks are all there at nature's suffrance.  You can see it in the sidewalks, cracked and broken between tiny green weeds, along 580 at the maze, the huge highway structures somehow overshadowed by the sheer presence of the Bay.  Sometimes it's more vivid: following little orange detour arrows around emergency crews that work frantically to find survivors between a sandwiched highway; blinking smoke and ash out of my eyes as I help carry a terrified cat to its owner's car, a firestorm raging less that two blocks away, eucalyptus popping in the distance.

As much as I detest my job, I love walking to BART in the afternoons.

It seems that I will be looking for a new job, after all.  If I get this promotion, I won't be able to go to school, and if I don't get this promotion, I won't be able to eat, so . . . yeah.  But I kind of knew this was coming, so that's okay.  Planning on hitting the restaurant circuit on Wednesday or Thursday.

If all goes well, my schedule come fall will be approximately as follows: MWF, get up way to fucking early (but a good two hours later than I get up now), jazz dance for an hour followed by back-to-back band and orchestra.  Then I get two hours for lunch, then cello class.  On Monday, I'll have physics lab until 5.  Tuesday and Thursday, I'd pretty much be at school from 11 a.m. on, but I'd have lots of breaks between classes.  C, then break, then physics, then an even longer break, then calculus.  It sounds absolutely exhausting, and if I can pull this off, I think I'll be a lot happier.  I've been rediscovering that I actually have energy when I'm doing things I care about.  I may pass on the dance class, since it's so damn early, but since my conception of early has been so drastically screwed by nine months of getting up at 5, it may not seem so bad.  I think it will mostly depend on how late I have to work on Sundays.
Our computer, bed and dresser are set up in our new place.  I hearby declare us officially moved.

"You know the world is going crazy when the best rapper is a white  
guy, the best golfer is a black guy, the tallest guy in the NBA is  
Chinese, the Swiss hold the America's Cup, France is accusing the U.S. of 
arrogance, Germany doesn't want to go to war, and the three most powerful men 
in America are named 'Bush', 'Dick', and 'Colon.' Need I say more?"  
- Chris Rock

<marquee><font size="5">WE GOT THE APARTMENT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!</font></marquee>

For those of you who haven't heard the details yet: washer and dryer in the unit, dishwasher, central heating and air, HUGE balcony, walking distance from BART, less than 5 minutes walking distance from wonderful Thai food, AND we can afford to live there.  We sign the lease and get the keyes on Thursday.  Who wants to come see our new place?  :-D
I would just like to take a moment to thank Paramount for raping my childhood.

On a happier note, there seem to be many affordable apartments available. Unfortunately, no one is advertizing for April yet, so we don't have any actual prospects, but the market is looking really good. I just have to keep up my no-worry mantra: "We are not in Santa Cruz; there are plenty of apartments. We are not in Santa Cruz . . ." Also I'm starting substitute teacher training for Mt Diablo on 4/10, and I should be receiving my application packet from Antioch (they're year-round) sometime next week. :)

For the past several years, I have worked at various customer-service-type jobs. I always just assumed that such jobs were inherently horrible and/or that my tendencies toward introversion made them seem a lot worse than they were. Lately, however, I've begun to wonder if there isn't something more going on. One of the things Borders employees are required to do is ask every customer they ring up if they would like to receive our email newsletter. After my first month there, I was informed that I was not gathering my expected quota of emails (3% of customers, if you're wondering). Since I had asked every single customer, and since I had received some downright hostile responses, I was somewhat irritated. So, I resolved to do better. I talked to my managers, asked for advice. Without fail, every male manager responded with some variant of "just ask; it works for me." When I questioned my managers about how would be the best way to difuse a hostile response (and I DO mean hostile -- about the response I'd expect if I'd asked for Driver's License, SSN and major credit card info), all of my female managers told me to just laugh it off, these things happen. With one exception, my male managers told me that they'd never had to deal with any such thing, pretty much implying that I was making this up or overreacting. So, I started watching the monthly postings of how many emails everyone had collected. Every month, in the six months I've worked there, every person who has broken the 5% mark has been over 30. Every person who has broken the 10% has also been a white man. No woman under 25 has managed to break 3%. After a couple of months of watching these figures, I started paying closer attention to employee-customer interactions, thinking back on some of the other jobs I've held, and really talking to friends and co-workers about their experiences, and what I've found really disturbs me. Women, particularly young women, in customer service postions seem to experience a much higher level of verbal abuse from customers. Almost all of the younger (in their 20s or late teens) women I've talked to have been grabbed by a customer who wanted their attention (what the hell ever happened to "excuse me, can I get some help, please?"). When engaged in friendly conversation with customers, men between the ages of 18 and 25 are often asked what they are studying in college (regardless of whether or not they're actually attending) while women of the same age are asked about their children (regardless of whether or not they have any, and please note the plural). But what bothers me the most, beyond the obvious sexism and agism, is that almost all of this ugly behavior is perpetrated by women! How can the female contingent of corporate America complain about salary inadequacies and glass ceilings if they're going to go out to dinner afterwards and physically accost and verbally abuse their waitress while cracking jokes with the young waiter serving the table next to theirs? As long as women with political and financial power are upholding sexist attitudes, there is no hope for equality. Maybe if I start referring to all of my female customers as "baby" or "sweetcheeks" they'll start to get it, but probably I'd just get fired.

Thirty-some hours of sleep later, I'm actually feeling nearly human.  Except for the strange vertigo-ish-feeling that's still around and the whole not being able to stay awake for very long.  Still, yesterday, I managed a whole 7-hour stretch when I was awake.  That's a vast improvement from two hours at a time.

On another note, Grandma will be here tomorrow.  It should be . . . interesting.  I think she's coming with us to pick out a Christmas tree.  Whee.

For those of you who actually ever knew it existed, I'm deleting my blackmagykwoman email addy; in excess of 50 spam mails per day is making it completely unusable.

Yes, I am actually posting in my livejournal.  A combination of exhaustion and persistant insomnia has kept me from having the energy to do much of anything for the past couple of weeks, but there are some very important things I need to share with all of you:

1) December 1, at 4 pm, at the Borders in Union Square, there will be Eddie Izzard.  :)

2) Tickets for the 12/21 Tori concert are on sale Sunday.  Double :)

3) First season of Babylon 5 goes on sale Tuesday.

4) Scarlet's Walk beats my punk ass down.  I mean, damn.

We now return you to your regularly scheduled LJing.

Note to self: Your life is plenty interesting; quit your bitching before someone gets hurt.

Note to everyone else: There must be a god because random chance just couldn't produce such an accurate facsimile of a higher power's twisted sense of humor.

Note to whomever's writing this crap: Your dialogue is trite and your plotline unoriginal.  Please take some writing classes before I'm forced to fall over laughing at the banality of my own internal monologue.

The preceeding message was brought to you by the letter 2 and the number e.

Congratulations, you're Ambassador Delenn, member of the grey council and shaper of the universe at large..
Which Babylon 5 Character are you?
Take the Babylon 5 Quizby Paradox
Of my hair.  And my eyeliner.  And my dress.  And my lingerie.  But my lipstick is dark red.  Life is good.
Which Member of the Endless Are You?
Which Evil Criminal are You?

Who are you? I'm your only friend I'm not your only friend but I'm a little glowing friend but really I'm not actually your friend but I am -Birdhouse in Your Soul They Might Be Giants How would you describe yourself? Perhaps I am a miscreation No one knows the truth There is no future here -Are You Out There? Dar Williams Are you male or female? I don't mean to sound like ond of the boys That's not what I'm trying to do I don't mean to be like one of the boys I just want you Now -I Want You Now Depeche Mode What's something you don't understand? Tears and fears and feeling proud To say "I love you" right out loud Dreams and shcemes and circus crowds I've looked at life that way But now old friends are acting strange They shake their heads, they say I've changed Well, something's lost, but something's gained In living every day I've looked at life from both sides now From win and lose And still somehow It's life's illusions I recall I really don't know life At all -Both Sides Now Joni Mitchell What is love? Peace in the struggle to find peace Comfort on the way to comfort And if I shed a tear I won't cage it I won't fear love And if I feel a rage I won't deny it I won't fear love -Fumbling Towards Ecstacy Sarah McLachlan Any words of wisdom? Only God says jump But I'll set the time 'Cause if he ever saw It was through these eyes of mine And if he ever suffered It was me who did his crying -Tomorrow Wendy Concrete Blonde If you could say one thing to your first love, what would it be? boy you still look pretty when you're putting the damage on -Putting the Damage On Tori Amos What do you think about America? I understand your causes, sympathize the motivation. But all the details of this war are just self-infatuation. -123 The Indigo Girls
I'm Diana, which ambiguous dyke are you? Quiz by Turi.

My customers:
Yesterday, I rang up probably 100 or so purchases.  Two of my customers were "Jane Do" (what do you bet she harbors matricidal fantasies?) and "Peta Griffin."  I was quite pleased

My coworkers:
I work with some pretty awsome people, including a guy who spent two hours discussing british comedy with me, a guy with long, manucured black fingernails (they're stunning), and a very sweet japanese woman who makes the most fantastic expressions when customers ask about the new Murakami book (most of them ask about "huh-ROO-kee MU-ruh-SAH-mee"; it's beautiful, in a horrific sort of way)

My utter stupidity:
Yesterday, I shut my skirt in the register and had to wave a manager over to unlock my drawer by jumping up and down since I couldn't get far enough to use the paging system.  


My electromagnetic field:
My bizarre interactions with electronic mechanisms has caused no end of annoyances.  Twice, my register has refused to print credit card slips.  Two different registers, in fact.  And the sensors seem to constantly think I'm scanning coupons.  Not using them, mind.  They think I'm ringing people up for coupons at the cost of $0.00.  I don't even know why the POS terminals have a way to register people purchasing coupons.  And I think I may have caused the power to go out today.  It went out first in the cafe when I bought my soda, and then kind of spread.  The registers all went down when I walked past them.  Oops.

After many trials and trevails, I am employed at a job that doesn't involve trying to fit my chest into men's shirts or having to recite the soups of the day for every customer sitting at the same table.

On the down side, I'm doing retail again, but there are too many pluses for me to mind much.  First, I'm going to be selling books.  I am going to spend 40 hours a week surrounded by and helping people locate books.  Not quite as good as being paid to read, but definitely up there.  Second, discounts on books, music and coffee.  Need I say more?  Third, at any point, I can have up to two books borrowed from the store.  It's like a library, except with new books and no late fees.  Fourth, during my interview, I mentioned that I'd done bookkeeping stuffs at NW, and the person who was interviewing me made speculative noises and explained that the guy in charge of bookkeeping was going to be trasferring to one of the new stores in a couple of months.  I would be so okay with doing bookkeeping again.  Fifth (and this made me so happy), I was asked to come in for training on Wednesday "morning" at 3:30pm.  I am working for someone who thinks 3:30pm is morning; this pleases me to no end.

I knew a Lit. degree had to be good for something . . .  ;)

As I type, my dear, darling husband is installing the new power supply and modem for our computer. Do you know what this means, kids?

HOT HOT PENTIUM 4 ACTION!!!!!!!
I feel like a total dork asking this, but it's been bugging me all day and, being me, I'm far too lazy to actually look it up or anything . . . What's the HTML tag for a horizontal line?

And I am still me

Alone amongst a thousand satellites
But always with you
Holding my hand

You touch the dark places
Kiss them awake like burning stars
And yet I am

In the darkness
The muddied shadow of humanity
And you are here

Within me
Without that which man has names for
You understand

Where no one can
Where the emptiness swallows me
You understand

And I am free

1) At lunch time, sit in your parked car with sunglasses on and point a hair dryer at passing cars. See if they slow down. 
2) Page yourself over the intercom. Don't disguise your voice. 
3) Insist that your e mail address is: Xena-Warrior-Princess@Uwillnotwin.com ....or Elvis-the-King@iseedeadpeople.com 
4) Every time someone asks you to do something, ask if they want fries with that. 
5) Put your garbage can on your desk and label it "IN." 
6) Pretend an unnatural fear of staplers. 
7) Put decaf in the coffee maker for 3 weeks. Once everyone has gotten over their caffeine addictions, switch to espresso.
8) In the memo field of all your checks, write "FOR SEXUAL FAVORS". 
9) Finish all your sentences with "In accordance with the prophecy." 
10) Don't use any punctuation 
11) As often as possible, skip rather than walk. 
12) Ask people what sex they are. Laugh hysterically after they answer. 
13) Specify that your drive-through order is "to go." 
14) Sing along at the opera. 
15) Go to a poetry recital and ask why the poems don't rhyme. 
16) Put mosquito netting around your cubicle. Play a tape of jungle sounds all day. 
17) Five days in advance, tell your friends you can't attend their party because you're not in the mood. 
18) Have your co-workers address you by your wrestling name, Rock Hard. 
19) When the money comes out of the ATM, scream"I Won!", "I Won!" 3rd time this week!!!" 
20) When leaving the zoo, start running towards the parking lot, yelling "Run for your lives, they're loose!" 
21) Tell your children over dinner, "Due to the economy, we are going to have to let one of you go." 
22) Send this e-mail to everyone in your address book, even if they sent it to you or have asked you not to send them stuff like this. And the final way to keep a healthy level of insanity.... 
23. Just remember every day that George W. Bush is president.

<hr>

I think I'm going to adopt number 9 to go with Sam's lovely number 8 and O's charming number 11, in accordance with the prophecy.  ;)
